The most likely clinical diagnosis is

questions.text: The malignancy associated with Stewart-trews syndrome is

A 60 year old lady underwent total abdominal hysterectomy. On the 3rd post operative day she
suddenly became breathless while returning from washroom. Her blood pressure recorded was 80150
mm of Hg. The most probable diagnosis is
A 52 year old female underwent MRM (Modified Radical Mastectomy). After few years, she developed lyrnphederna of the ipsilateral arm. Which of the following malignancy can develop in her arm ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) Lymphangiosarcoma Explanation: Some important point regarding breast cancer surgery: Breast conservative breast surgery means wide local excision of the primary tumour, whole breast radiation and a separate axillary dissection The main indications for breast conservative surgery are as follows: (i) Tumour size is of paramount importance. A single clinical and mammographic lesion measuring 4 cm or less without signs of local advancement (T1, T2, < 4> 4 cm may also be treated by breast conserving surgery in patients with large breast. In case of small breasts even smaller tumours may require mastectomy (ii) There is no age limit. Primary systemic chemotherapy may reduce size of large tumours to allow such surgery Contraindications of breast conservation surgery are-Tumours> 4 cm in size (T4), extensive nodal metastasis (N2) with distant metastasis (M1), Fixity of tumour with underlying muscles or overlying skin, multicentricity of the tumour which is determined by mammography, central lesions when nipple has to be sacrificed, poor tumour differentiation, multifocal disease, local recurrence, patient preference. Relative contraindications are-young patient (under 35 years), extensive ductal carcinoma-in-situ and widespread lymphatic invasion.


Local recurrence is more common in younger women and in those with high-grade tumours and involved resection margins. ? The presence of metastatic disease within the axillary lymph nodes remains the best single marker for prognosis; although treatment of the axilla not affect long-term survival, indicating that the axillary nodes act not as a 'reservoir for disease but as a marker for metastatic potential. ? Axillary surgery should not be combined with radiotherapy to the axilla because of excess morbidity

Which of the following statements regarding Ogilvie's syndrome are correct ?
1. I. It presents as acute large bowel mechanical obstruction 
2. Marked caeca' dilatation is a common feature on X-ray abdomen 
3. Caecal perforation is a well recognized complication of this condition 
4. Intravenous Neostigmine is used for the treatment of this condition 
Select the correct answer using the code given below :
questions.solution:
Solution - Correct Answer (B) 2, 3 and 4  Some important point regarding Ogilvie's
syndrome (Colonic pseudo-obstruction) ? Condition of distension of the colon, with signs and
symptoms of acute colonic obstruction, in the absence of an actual physical cause of the obstruction
? Factors associated with pseudo obstruction metabolic (diabetes, hypokalaemia, uraemia,
myxodoema, intermittent porphyria), severe trauma (especially to the lumbar spine and pelvis),
shock (burns, myocardial infarction, stroke), idiopathic, septicaemia, postoperative (for example
fractured neck of femur), retroperitoneal irritation [blood, urine, enzymes (pancreatitis), tumour),
drups (tricyclic antidepressants. phenothiazines, laxatives) Secondary gastrointestinal involvement,
scleroderma. Chagas' disease. ? X-ray abdomen show evidence of colonic obstruction, with marked
caecal distension and later perforation being a common feature. Urgent colonoscopy or a single
contrast water-soluble barium enema or CT require for confirmation. Mechanical obstruction should
be rule out. ? Treatment is identifiable cause and if ineffective, IV neostigmine should be given.
During this procedure, the patient should sit on a commode. If neostigmine is ineffective,
colonoscopic decompression should be performed. Caecal perforation is more likely if the caecal
diameter increases acutely or size >14 cm (10-12 cm in CSDT; normal diameter is 7cm.).
Sympathetic blockade by epidural anesthesia has been shown to relieve colonic pseudo-obstruction
successfully. Surgery is having high morbidity and mortality and should be reserved for those with
impending perforation/ perforation when other treatments have failed.

A 50 year old male patient presents to the emergency with sudden onset of upper abdominal
pain, nausea, vomiting and haematemesis. On examination, PR = 1061 min, BP = 100/70 mm Hg and
pallor is present. CECT abdomen reveals a large exophytic tumor of size 13 x 8 cm at the fundus of
the stomach. On upper GI endoscopy, the mucosa overlying the tumor is intact. The staining for
CD117 in the upper GI endoscopic biopsy is positive. The most probable clinical diagnosis in this
patient is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) Gastrointestinal stromal tumor Explanation: Some
immunohistochemical stains used for tumours Cell type/site of origin: Epithelial (carcinoma):
cytokeratins ? Lymphoid (lymphoma): CD45, CD3, CD20 ? Melanocytic (melanoma): S100, HMB45,
Melan A ? Neuroendocrine (carcinoid, small sell carcinoma): synaptophysin, chromogranin, CD56 ?
Endothelial cell markers (vascular invasion or vascular neoplasm: CD31 ? Myoid: desmin, actin
Prognosis and treatment: ? Breast and gastric carcinomas: HER2 ? Neuroendocrine tumours: Ki67
labelling index Site of origin/cell type ? Prostate: prostate-specific antigen (PSA) ? Lung (bronchogenic
): thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1) ? Thyroid: thyroglobulin ? Colorectum: cytokeratin 20 (CK20),
CDX2 Liver: HepPar ? Gastrointestinal stromal tumour (GIST): CD117 (KIT protein), calcium-activated
chloride Channel (DOG-1) Screening for mutations ? Colorectal carcinoma: mismatch repair genes
(MLHI, MSH2, MSH6, PMS2)

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a classical symptom of acute appendicitis ?
Among the extra intestinal manifestations of Crohn's disease which one of the following is related to the disease activity ?

The Model for End Stage Liver Disease (MELD) score includes which of the following variables ? 
1. Serum bilirubin 
2. Serum albumin 
3. Serum creatinine 
4. International Normalised Ratio (INR) 
Select the correct answer using the code given below :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 1, 3 and 4 The MELD score calculation incorporates three key variables
that reflect different aspects of liver function and overall systemic health in patients with advanced
liver disease: Serum Bilirubin: This measures the liver's ability to process and excrete bile. Elevated
bilirubin levels indicate impaired liver function in this regard, often due to cholestasis or severe
hepatocellular damage, and are associated with a worse prognosis. Serum Creatinine: This parameter
assesses kidney function. In advanced liver disease, renal impairment (e.g., hepatorenal syndrome) is
a common and severe complication, significantly worsening the patient's outlook. Therefore, higher
creatinine levels contribute to a higher MELD score. International Normalized Ratio (INR): The INR
reflects the liver's synthetic function, specifically its ability to produce clotting factors (e.g., factors II,
VII, IX, X). A prolonged INR indicates impaired synthetic function, suggesting severe liver damage and
a higher risk of bleeding complications. These three variables are combined using a specific
mathematical formula to calculate the MELD score, which provides a numerical value that correlates
with the 90-day mortality risk in patients with chronic liver disease. Incorrect Options: A. 1, 2 and 3:
This option includes Serum albumin (2) instead of INR (4). While serum albumin is an important
indicator of liver synthetic function and is included in other liver scoring systems like the Child-Pugh
score, it is not a component of the standard MELD score calculation. B. 1, 2 and 4: This option also
includes Serum albumin (2) and omits Serum creatinine (3). As explained above, serum albumin is
not part of the standard MELD score, and serum creatinine is a critical component reflecting renal
function, which is highly relevant in end-stage liver disease. D. 2, 3 and 4: This option entirely omits
Serum bilirubin (1) and includes Serum albumin (2). Serum bilirubin is one of the foundational
variables of the MELD score, reflecting the liver's excretory capacity, and its exclusion makes this
option incorrect. Serum albumin, again, is not a MELD variable.

Which of the following statements regarding hepatic adenomas are correct ? 
1. They are almost exclusively seen in females aged 25-50 years 
2. They are associated with use of oral contraceptive pills 
3. They do not have any malignant potential 
4. Majority are detected incidentally on imaging
Select the correct answer using the code given below :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 1, 2 and 4 Explanation: Some important point regarding Hepatic
adenoma ? Benign liver tumours seen almost exclusively in women of child bearing age (between 25
and 50 years). ? Well-defined and vascular, homogeneous mass of normal-appearing hepatocytes
without bile ducts or central veins ? Specific cause is unknown but classically associated with use of
the oral contraceptive pill (more in mestranol-containing compounds); also associated with glycogen
storage disease, diabetes, exogenous steroids, and pregnancy. Some lesions may regress after
discontinuation of the oral contraceptive pill ? Solitary (2/3); about half of patients are asymptomatic.
Large tumor (8-15 cm) causes symptoms (right upper quadrant pain). The majority are found
incidentally on imaging although up to one-third may present with pain because of rupture or
bleeding. There is strong association of acute bleeding episodes from adenoma with pregnancy.
Adenomas are recognized as having malignant potential, with up to 10

1. Submucosa of the stomach and duodenum 
2. Liver 
3. Small bowel mesentery 
4. Splenic hilum 
Select the correct answer using the code given below :

choices.text: Rugs between gall bladder fossa and right hepatic vein
Runs between gall bladder fossa and right branch of portal vein
Runs between gall bladder fossa and middle hepatic vein
Runs between gall bladder fossa and left branch of portal vein

questions.text: Which one of the following statements regarding Cantlie's line is correct ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) Runs between gall bladder fossa and middle hepatic vein Explanation:
Anatomy of liver Liver is divided into 8 segments. The liver is divided into right and left functional unit
along the line between the gallbladder fossa and the middle hepatic vein (Cantlies line). Liver
segments (V-VIII) to the right of this line (right lobe of liver) are supplied by the right hepatic artery
and the right branch of the portal vein, and drain bile through right hepatic ?uct. To the left of this
line (segments I-IV), is the left liver, which is Supplied by the left branch of the hepatic artery and the
left portal vein branch, and drains bile through the left hepatic duct.

1. Pseudomyxoma peritonei 
2. Trauma 
3. Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) 
4. Hypersplenism 
Select the correct answer using the code given below

A 45 year old female patient presents with a painless firm abdominal swelling of size 10 x 8 cm
near the umbilicus. The swelling can be moved freely in a plane at right angle to the line of
attachment of the mesentery. The most probable clinical diagnosis in this patient is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) Mesenteric cyst Explanation: Some important clinical features of
mesenteric cysts: ? Occur most commonly in adults with a mean age of 45 years, twice as common in
women, one third in <15 years ages, mean age of children affected is 4.9 years ? Most common
presentation is of a painless abdominal fluctuant swelling near the umbilicus, swelling moves freely in
a plane at right angles to the attachment of the mesentery (Tillaux's sign), a zone of resonance
around the cyst. Other features are recurrent attacks of abdominal pain with or without vomiting
(pain resulting from recurring temporary impaction of a food bolus in a segment of bowel narrowed
by the cyst or possibly from torsion of the mesentery) and acute abdominal catastrophe, due to:
torsion of that portion of the mesentery, rupture of the cyst as a result of a comparatively trivial
accident, haemorrhage into the cyst, infection. Chylolymphatic cyst ? Commonest variety. ? Arises in
congenitally misplaced lymphatic tissue that has no efferent communication with lymphatic system. ?
Arises most frequently in the mesentery of the ileum. ? Thin-walled cyst composed of connective
tissue lined by flat endothelium, is filled with clear lymph or less frequently with chyle. ? Cyst is
almost often unilocular than multilocular. ? Cyst is almost invariably solitary. ? Cyst has a blood
supply independent of that of adjacent intestine, thereby enucleation is possible without the
necessity of resection of gut. Enterogenous cyst ? Derived either from diverticulum of the mesenteric
border of the intestine, which becomes sequestrated from the intestinal canal during embryonic life
or from a duplication of intestine. ? Thicker wall than a chylolymphatic cyst, and it is lined by mucous
membrane, sometime ciliated, content is mucinous and either colorless or yellowish brown from
bygone hemorrhage. ? Muscle in the wall of an enterogenous cyst. and the bowel with which it is in
contact has a common blood supply, consequently removal of the cyst always entails resection of
related portion of intestine. Urogenital remnant ? A cyst developing in the retroperitoneal space ?
D/D- large hydronephrosis (confirmed by scanning or urography) ? Retroperitoneal cyst can seldom
be distinguished with certainty from a retroperitoneal tumour until displayed at operation. ?
Uunilocular or multilocular. ? Cysts are believed to be derived from a remnant of the wolffian duct, in
which case they are filled with clear fluid.

questions.text:
A 45 year old male patient, a known case of left inguinal hernia presents to the emergency with
an acute onset of pain abdomen associated with nausea, vomiting and abdominal distension. His
pulse rate is 102/min, BP is 100/70 mm Hg and respiratory rate is 24/min. On local examination, the
skin overlying the swelling is tense and erythernatous. There is localized tenderness over the
swelling; the swelling is irreducible with absence of cough impulse. The most probable clinical
diagnosis in this patient is
Mayo's repair is done for
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Umbilical hernia Explanation: Classical open umbilical hernia repair described by Mayo. Defects up to 2 cm in diameter may be sutured primarily with minimal tension, for lager defect mesh reinforcement will be beneficial.

questions.text: The commonest organism causing Suppurative Otitis Media is

A patient of road traffic accident presents to the emergency with increasing restlessness and
difficulty in breathing. The respiratory rate is 26 breaths/minute; there are distended neck veins;
trachea is deviated to the right side with hyper-resonant note and absence of breath sounds on the
left side. Which of the following statements are correct ? 
1. The most probable clinical diagnosis is left tension pneumothorax 
2. immediate chest decompression using wide bore cannula in left second intercostal space should be done 
3. Immediate chest X-ray should be done to confirm the clinical diagnosis 
4. Definitive chest tube insertion in left fifth intercostal space should be done 
Select the correct answer using the code given below :
Positron Emission Tomography (PET) used in Preoperative staging of Gastro Oesophageal tumours is to detect
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) Distant metastatic disease Explanation: Some important investigation in
esophageal carcinoma  Endoscopy is the first-line investigation. It provides direct view of the
oesophageal mucosa and any lesion. Specimens taken for cytology and/ or histology via the
endoscope are crucial for accurate diagnosis. The combination of histology and cytology is having
diagnostic accuracy to more than 95%.. It is difficult to visualise mediastinal structures with
transcutaneous ultrasonography. Therefore used mainly to assess spread to the liver.  CT from the
neck to the pelvis with intravenous contrast is mostly used to identify distant haematogenous
metastases with high accuracy (94-100% ). MRI doesn't have additional benefit over CT except
exposure of ionising radiation.  Endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS) determines the depth of spread of
a malignant tumour through the oesophageal wall (T1-3), the invasion of adjacent organs (T4) and
metastasis to lymph nodes (NO or N1). Structures smaller than 5 mm can be clearly seen which CT
can't detect.  Positron emission tomography (PET) with CT (PET-CT) in the context of cancer staging
relies on the generally high metabolic activity of tumours compared with normal tissues. The patient
is given a small dose of the [18F]fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG). The main value of PET-CT is the
identification of distant metastatic disease not seen on CT alone. In responders PET activity after
chemotherapy might reduce and persistence of PET activity seems to be a poor prognostic sign.

questions.text:
Which of the following are correct about ectopic ureters ? 
1. They are more common in males 
2. They drain the upper pole of kidney 
3. They are associated with duplex ureter 
4. They may cause incontinence 
Select the correct answer using the code given below :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 2, 3 and 4 Explanation: Ectopic Ureters:- Almost always associated with
ureteric duplication and 10% are bilateral. Female: male = 7:1. It drains the upper pole of the kidney
and inserts into the bladder more distally towards the bladder neck. In females, it opens either into
the urethra below the sphincter or into the vagina and may be incontinent. A female voids normally
but complain dribbling of urine. In male, opening is above the external urethral sphincter so the
patient is continent. An ectopic ureteric orifice in a male at the apex of the trigone, in the posterior
urethra, in a seminal vesicle or in an ejaculatory duct is likely to be functionally abnormal and
infection is common. A refluxing ureter may need re-implanting. In female it often drains
hydronephrotic and chronically infected renal tissue and is best excised. Duplex renal pelvis and
ureter:- It is a common anomaly. Unilateral duplication is six times more common than bilateral and
in left side is more common; more common in girls. It may be complete of incomplete (Y shaped)
Ureter develop from normal bud is non refluxing and from lower bud, which will drain the lower pole
of the kidney and ends in laterally to ureteric orifice with short submocosal tunnel and vice versa. It is
associated with vesico-ureteric reflux (VUR). In adults the condition is usually asymptomatic but
children with duplex ureters often have VUR. Ureterococle:- A ureterocoele is a cystic enlargement of
the intramural ureter, due to atresia of the ureteric orifice. F:M-4:1, 10% are bilateral; Almost
exclusively in Caucasians. Ureters frequently drain the upper pole and are often associated with
dysplastic or non-functional renal tissue. Children they usually present with infection, in adults with
stones in the lower ureter. The classic sign of a ureterocoele on excretion urography is 'cobra head.
On cystoscopy, a bulging, translucent swelling involving the ureteric orifice is typical which fills with
and empties of urine with ureteric peristalsis. Treatment is surgical excision with re-implantation of
the ureter. Endoscopic incision may cause reflux Congenital megaureter: - Uncommon condition,
ureteric dilatation with or without obstruction; may be bilateral and associated with other congenital
abnormalities. Ureteric orifice looks normal on cystoscopy. Renal stones can easily form in the dilated
systems. Obstruction excluded by antegrade pressure-flow study (Whitaker test) in which a
nephrostomy. Retrocaval ureter:- Rarely, the right ureter passes behind the inferior vena cava rather
which lead to obstruction and the need to surgically move the ureter to lie anterior to the IVC.

questions.text: Which one of the following is a Nephrotoxic anaesthetic agent ?

A comatose patient after sustaining severe head injury has been admitted in neurosurgical ICU. Which of the following parameters should ideally be maintained in this patient ? 
1. pCO2 = 4.5 5.0 kPa (33-38 mm Hg) 
2. MAP = 80  90 min of Hg 
3. p02> 11 kPa (> 80 mm Hg) 
4. Na+ < 130 meq/L
Select the correct answer using the code given below
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) CPP (75-105 mmHg) = MAP (90-110 mmHg) - ICP (5-15 mmHg). Normal cerebral blood flow (CBE) is about 55 ml per minute for every 100 grams of brain tissue. Ischaemia results when this 16 rate drops < 20>

questions.text: Ideal weight gain during pregnancy for a woman with normal BMI should be
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 11-16 kg Explanation: The total weight gain in singleton pregnancy for a
healthy woman averages 11 kg (24 lb); 1 kg in 1" trimester and 5 kg each in 2nd and 3 trimester.
Amount of water retained is 6.5 kg. Reproductive Weight Gain: 6 kg. Fetus-3.3 kg, placenta-0.6 kg
and liquor-0.8 kg, uterus-0.9 kg and breasts-0.4 kg approx. Accumulation of fat (mainly) and
protein-3.5 kg approx. Net Maternal Weight Gain: 6 kg Increase in blood volume-1.3 kg, Increase in
extracellular fluid-1.2 kg approx.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct with respect to antenatal USG examination ? 
1. It helps in detecting gross fetal anomalies 
2. It helps in identifying multiple pregnancies 
3. It helps in identifying viable pregnancy 
4. Best dating is possible with third trimester ultrasound scan 
Select the correct answer using the code given below :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 1, 2 and 3 only Explanation: First trimester scan either transabdominal
(TAS) or transvaginal (TVS) helps to detect early pregnancy, accurate dating, number of fitos, gross
fetal anomalies, any uterine or adnexal pathology, suspected ectopic pregnancy, vaginal bleeding,
anencephaly, suspected molar pregnancy gestational age((Fetal gestational age is best determined
by measuring the CRL between 7 and 12 weeks (variation & 5 days), to confirm cardiac activity,
screening of aneuploidy Second and third trimester scan shows gestational age, cervical
insufficiency, suspected multiple pregnancy, liquor volume (poly oligohydramnios), placenta previa/
abruption, suspected uterine malformation, cases with PROM, fetal growth (FGR). fetal presentation
(breech, face), fetal well-being (BPP) assessment, screening fetal anomalies, as an adjunct to:
(amniocentesis, CVS, cordocentesis, fetal therapy ECV), Uterine size: Either> dates or < dates

choices.text: All pregnant mothers from 16 weeks onwards
Only those pregnant mothers who have Hb < 10 gm%
Only those pregnant mothers who are not eating green vegetables
All pregnant mothers since 6 weeks of pregnancy

questions.text: During pregnancy iron supplementation is needed for
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) All pregnant mothers from 16 weeks onwards

choices.text: Is present on both lower limbs and abdomen
Is associated with cardiac or renal pathology
Is usually of moderate or severe grade
Disappears or markedly reduced on rest

questions.text: The clinical feature of physiological edema in pregnancy
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) Disappears or markedly reduced on rest Explanation: Physiological
edema: Due to increased venous pressure of the inferior extremities by the gravid uterus pressing on
the common iliac veins. Features are: slight degree (ankle edema), usually confined to one leg, more
on right; not associated with any other features of preeclampsia or proteinuria; disappears on rest
alone; other pathologies like cardiac, renal and hematological disease are absent. The causes of
edema in pregnancy are physiological, pre-eclampsia, anemia, hypoproteinemia, cardiac failure, and
nephrotic syndrome. Edema in dependent part is physiological in other parts may be pathological.

questions.text: Which one of the following is correct regarding obesity and infertility ?

questions.text:
Which of the following are causes of GnRH dependent precocious puberty ? 
1. Constitutional 
2.Tubercular Encephalitis 
3. McCune-Albright syndrome 
4. Primary hypothyroidism 
Select the correct answer using the code given below :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 1 and 2 1. Constitutional (Idiopathic) Precocious Puberty: Explanation:
This is the most common cause of central precocious puberty, especially in girls. "Idiopathic" means
there's no identifiable underlying medical condition or structural abnormality causing it. It's simply an
early activation of the normal puberty process. Is it GnRH-dependent? YES. By definition, this is a
form of central precocious puberty, which is driven by the premature pulsatile release of GnRH from
the hypothalamus. 2. Tubercular Encephalitis (and other CNS lesions): Explanation: The
hypothalamus, where GnRH is produced, is located in the brain. Various central nervous system
(CNS) conditions can disrupt the normal regulation of the HPG axis, leading to its premature
activation. These conditions can include tumors (like hypothalamic hamartomas, astrocytomas),
hydrocephalus, radiation to the brain, and inflammatory or infectious processes like tubercular
encephalitis or sarcoidosis. These lesions can either directly stimulate GnRH neurons or remove
normal inhibitory influences on them. Is it GnRH-dependent? YES. The pathology directly affects the
brain's control over GnRH release, leading to its premature and pulsatile secretion. 3. McCune-
Albright Syndrome: Explanation: This is a genetic disorder caused by a somatic mutation in the GNAS
gene. This mutation leads to autonomous hyperfunction of various endocrine glands. In the context of
precocious puberty, it primarily causes the ovaries (in girls, more rarely testes in boys) to produce
estrogen independently of pituitary stimulation. This is often due to recurring ovarian cysts that
secrete estrogen. Is it GnRH-dependent? NO (primarily). The precocious puberty in McCune-Albright
Syndrome is a classic example of GnRH-independent (peripheral) precocious puberty. The gonads are
producing hormones autonomously, not in response to premature GnRH/LH/FSH secretion. While
prolonged exposure to high levels of sex steroids in these children can eventually "centralize" and
lead to secondary GnRH-dependent puberty, the primary mechanism of precocity in McCune-Albright
Syndrome itself is peripheral. 4. Primary Hypothyroidism: Explanation: Severe, long-standing primary
hypothyroidism (where the thyroid gland is underactive) can occasionally lead to precocious puberty,
a condition known as Van Wyk-Grumbach syndrome. In primary hypothyroidism, the pituitary gland
overproduces Thyroid-Stimulating Hormone (TSH) in an attempt to stimulate the failing thyroid. At
very high concentrations, TSH can cross-react with and activate FSH receptors on the gonads, leading
to independent sex steroid production. Is it GnRH-dependent? NO. This is another classic example of
GnRH-independent (peripheral) precocious puberty. The high TSH levels directly stimulate the
gonads, bypassing the GnRH-LH-FSH axis. The gonadotropin levels (LH/FSH) are typically low or
prepubertal in this condition.

questions.text:
Which of the following are indications of vaginal examinations during labour ? 
1. To stretch the vagina intermittently
2. At the onset of labour 
3. To monitor progress of labour 
4. Following rupture of membranes 
Select the correct answer using the code given below :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 2, 3 and 4 Explanation: Indication of vaginal examination during labour:
Whatever aseptic preparation done, there is some infection after rupture of the membranes so it
should be restricted to minimum. It is done at the onset of labor to confirm the onset of labor, to
detect precisely the presenting part and its position and to assess the pelvis, to judge the progress of
labor noting the dilatation of the cervix and descent of the head in relation to the spines Le station;
following rupture of the membranes to exclude cord prolapse, whenever any interference is
contemplated or to diagnose precisely the beginning of second stage.

asymptomatic monitoring at home I symptomatic monitoring at hospital.

questions.text:
Consider the following statements : Statement-
1 : In fetal growth restriction there is always oligohydramnios Statement-
2 : In fetal growth restriction there is placental insufficiency leading to redistribution of blood flow to fetal brain shunting it from fetal kidney. Which one of the following is correct in respect of the above statements ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) Statement-2 is true but Statement-l is false Explanation: Statement 1 is
not true. Amniotic fluid can be normal in early IUGR. As severity of IUGR increases hypoxia sets in
and hence the limited blood supply to the fetus is redistributed. Blood flow is more towards brain and
relatively less to the renal arteries. This is seen as brain sparing effect by doppler studies. Decreased
blood flow to renal arteries leads to less production of fetal urine. Fetal urine has major contribution
to amniotic fluid. Hence oligohydroamnios sets in. If there is oligohydroamnios along with IUGR, it is
associated with more morbidity. Fetal Growth Restriction is said to be present in those babies whose
birth weight is below the 10th percentile of the average for the gestational age. It is due to reduced
availability of nutrients in the mother or its reduced transfer to fetus by placenta, ultimately reduced
utilization by fetus. Liver glycogen content is reduced. Renal and pulmonary contribution to amniotic
fluid is diminished due to reduction in blood flow to these organs which leads to oligohydramnios. As
H& B writes, chronic fetal distress means intrauterine fetal growth restriction and low volume of
liquor, and acute fetal distress means Bradycardia and meconium stained liquor. In 5% of IUGR
amniotic fluid are normal, in oligohydramnios the incidence of IUGR is 40%.

questions.text:
Consider the following in respect of Orrneloxifene : 
1. It is a research product of Central Drug Research Institute, Lucknow 
2. It is a steroidal compound 
3. It is a potent antiestrogen with weak estrogenic properties 
4. It does not inhibit ovulation Which of the above are correct ?

Steroidal contraceptives available in the basket of contraceptive choice from Ministry of Health &
Family Welfare, Government of India are
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) Monophasic Explanation: Monophasic pill contains an estrogen and a
progestin in fixed dose for all the days of a treatment cycle. Triphasic pills have been introduced to
permit reduction in total steroid dose without compromising efficacy. The estrogen dose is kept
constant (or varied slightly between 30-40 g), while the amount of progestin is low in the first phase
and progressively higher in the second and third phases. Phasic pills are particularly recommended
for women over 35 years of age and for those with no withdrawal bleeding or breakthrough bleeding
while on monophasic pill, or when other risk factors are present. Government of India recommended
Mala N (Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg+ Ethinyl Estradiol 30 mcg) 21 +7 iron tablets (spacer pills) for
hormone free interval.

8+9+13=30 SMR observed death/expected death x 100. i. e. 30/25x100-12

questions.text: The amount of iron lost per 28 day cycle in menstruating women is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 12.5 mg Explanation: The total daily iron loss of an adult is around 1 mg, and about 12.5 mg per 28 days cycle in menstruation. Intrauterine devices have been shown to increase the average monthly blood loss by between 35 to 146 per cent depending upon the type of the device, on the other hand, hormonal contraceptive decrease menstrual blood loss by about 50 per cent.

questions.text:
The voluntary scheme under which any obstetrics and gynaecology specialist, lady doctor/MBBS
doctor can volunteer themselves for providing safe motherhood service is called
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) Vande Mataram Scheme Explanation: Vandemataram scheme: - This is
a voluntary scheme wherein any obstetrics and gynaecology specialist, maternity home, nursing
home, lady doctor/MBBS doctor can volunteer themselves for providing safe motherhood services.
The enrolled doctors will display 'Vandemataram logo' at their clinic. Iron and Folic Acid tablets, oral
pills, TT injections etc. will be provided by the respective district medical officers for free distribution
to beneficiaries. The cases needing special care and treatment can be referred to the government
hospitals.

questions.text:
A 2 year old child has presented for vaccination, who has never been vaccinated earlier. As per
the Universal Immunization Program, which among the following vaccines will be administered to the
child on the first visit ? 
1. BCG vaccine 
2. DPT- 1 vaccine 
3. Hepatitis B vaccine 
4. Measles vaccine
Select the correct answer using the code given below :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) DPT-1 vaccine, Hepatitis B vaccine, and Measles vaccine 1. BCG
Vaccine  Not Given  BCG is recommended at birth or up to 1 year of age.  Not administered after 1
year because the risk of severe adverse effects increases and the protective effect diminishes. 2.
DPT-1 Vaccine Can be given up to 7 years of age (as DPT). For older children, Td (Tetanus-diphtheria)
is given instead of DPT. 3. Hepatitis B Vaccine Can be given at any age, following the appropriate
schedule. Typically 3 doses are given at 0, 1, and 6 months intervals. 4. Measles Vaccine Measles
vaccine is given up to 5 years of age if not previously vaccinated. Usually as MR (Measles-Rubella)
vaccine in catch-up.

questions.text:
Which of the following agencies are playing a key role in running of the "COVAX" initiative against COVID-19 
1. GAVI, the Vaccine Alliance 
2. World Health Organisation(WHO) 
3. Ford Foundation 
4. Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations (CEPI) 
Select the correct answer usingthe code given below
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 1, 2 and 4 Explanation: COVAX is co-led by Gavi, the Coalition for
Epidemic Preparedness Innovations (CEPI) and WHO with key delivery partner UNICEF. Its aim is to
accelerate the development and manufacture of COVID-19 vaccines, and to guarantee fair and
equitable access for every country in the world.
